conclusion: Shadows are influenced by the position of the light source relative to the objects and the ground.
When the light source moves closer to the objects (downward), the shadows generally become larger because the angle of light hitting the objects becomes more oblique.
The position of the shadows on the ground also shifts depending on the direction of the light source.
The shadow (A) is relatively small and close to the hand-like object.
When the light source moves downward, shadow A will increase in size because the light rays spread more as the source gets closer.
Shadow A will also shift slightly outward from the hand-like object, depending on the light's angle.
The shadow (B) is small and circular, close to the circular object.
When the light source moves downward, shadow B will grow larger and become more elongated.
The position of shadow B will shift outward slightly.
The shadow (C) is elongated and points away from the bottle-like object.
When the light source moves downward, shadow C will increase in length and become more distorted due to the oblique angle of the light.
The position of shadow C will shift outward further from the bottle-like object.
The shadow (D) is small and close to the tape-like object.
When the light source moves downward, shadow D will grow larger and become more elongated.
The position of shadow D will shift outward from the tape-like object.
When the light source moves downward, all shadows (A, B, C, and D) will increase in size due to the closer proximity of the light source, causing the light rays to spread more.
When the light source moves downward, all shadows (A, B, C, and D) will shift outward from their respective objects as the light source's angle becomes more oblique.
